Hi Elliotte,

All good points, and I'm in general agreement with everything=
 you say below.

Again, all I was trying to do was to fight against the dog=
matic "never
expose a protected method if you don't have to". As you rightf=
ully point out
in your message below, this mailing-list is comprised of exp=
erts who have a
good grasp of the compromises involved in making such decis=
ions, and if one
of them decides that there is some potential to be gained =
by exposing a
protected method, they should follow their instinct and go ah=
ead, even if
that potential is unseen at the time of writing and, more impo=
rtantly, even
if it goes again the Agile Principles.

That's called intuiti=
on, and listening to it once in a while is a duty,
along with questioning a=
bsolute statements such as "YAGNI".

--
Cedric

n most cases.

 accept that other

 which, most of the

ms).

>
> Actually, I'd turn that back on you. Different people have diffe=
rent
> experiences and different needs, but these experiences and needs are=
 not
> equal in numbers or importance. The programmers who hang out on mail=
ing
> lists like this one (especially this one) are a very highly
> self-se=
lected group. They are in many ways much more theoretically and
> abstractl=
y inclined than 90% of working developers. Most programmers who
> write boo=
ks about programming and who design and publish libraries are
> really way =
beyond the typical working developer. Not a surprise: some
> programmers ar=
e experts in programming and some are experts in insurance
> or financial d=
erivatives or shock wave modeling or something else. We
> can't all be expe=
rts in everything. But these mailing lists attract the
> meta-programmers: =
the programmers who are experts in programming.
>
> Guess what? We're weird=
, even among programmers. We are much more
> comfortable with abstraction t=
han even other typical programmers. Design
> patterns, factory methods, int=
erfaces, inheritance, polymorphism, and
> anything beyond simple data encap=
sulation is way beyond the comfort
> level of most actual programmers. A li=
brary designed for ease of use by
> a typical programmer needs to focus on =
the 90% rather than the 10%. If
> you gauge the audience for a tool by the =
programmers who hang out in
> forums like this one, you're going to miss th=
e vast body of programmers
> who don't.
>
> What you are in effect arguing =
is that you don't want to be held back by
> the needs of the many. You can =
safely use extra extension points, and
> therefore they should be there. Bu=
t most programmers don't feel this
> way. Most of them can at least safely =
ignore the extra methods. They
> probably won't shoot themselves in the foo=
t even if we give them plenty
> of bullets. However the sheer complexity of=
 adding all these extra
> extension points make the classes so much harder =
to use that the cost to
> the many outweighs the benefits to the few.
>
> S=
ometimes we do need subclassing and extra extension points, but not
> that =
many and not that often; even when considering only the most
> abstractly i=
nclined of programmers. Extension points are not without
> cost. There's is=
 or should be a significant hurdle to be jumped before
> adding a new publi=
shed method. Even if the method is inherently useful
> and has no correspon=
ding problems, it still needs to be useful enough.
> It's not enough that o=
ne or a few people might use a method. It needs to
> be pretty clear that l=
arge percentage of a library's users are going to
> take advantage of the f=
eature, or that it be extremely important to a
> smaller but still sizeable=
 percentage.
>
> We can argue about exactly where to put the line: how usef=
ul to how many
> people does a method need to be before we add it. However =
that number is
> quite a bit higher then 1. It is certainly higher than 0. =
That a feature
> might someday be used by someone, but we aren't quite sure=
 who or when,
> is not sufficient grounds to include it. There needs to be =
a positive
> decision that a feature will be useful before it's added. Feat=
uritis is
> as damaging to APIs as it is to applications.
